>>1316119
If you could draw twenty finished panels like this in a day, and maintain this level of quality, you would be at the skill level of a slightly below mediocre mangaka.
I've included an image for comparison. On the left is Teisou Gyakuten Sekai, a manga with very poor composition that was successful because of its creative and unique story, and on the right is Black Joke, a manga that was successful mostly because of its fantastic composition.
Your work is much closer to the left than the right.
The real challenge though is being able to create art of consistent quality on a strict deadline.
Part of the reason that Black Joke looks so good is because it was published in a monthly magazine, meaning the illustrator had over four times as long a deadline as most.

I can't offer much specific advice as most of the pieces you've provided appear to be unfinished, but if I was in your shoes I would put additional focus on my faces and try to make my breasts look a little less fake.

In a Japanese visual novel, how do you indicate that a character is having an internal monologue or thinking to himself? In English, I would just use parenthesis, like:
>(Ah, so that's what happened...)
Can the same thing be done with written Japanese? And if so, are there special Japanese parenthesis characters that are used instead of our traditional ( or ) characters? Thank you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1315869
Oh damn, that’s what I use to indicate spoken dialogue. Should I use something else?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1315869
Random anon here, I would've thought that would be used for spoken dialogue too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: bump

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: bump

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Bump

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In visual novels all non-dialogue text is written without any special punctuation. Image is an example.
This is also how regular novels are written in Japanese.
This is also how novels are written in English too; if you read Lolita it starts with
>Lolita, life of my life, fire of my loins. My sin, my soul.
not
>(Lolita, life of my life, fire of my loins.) (My sin, my soul.)
That would be silly.

Spoken text is written with 「」, the Japanese equivalent of double quotation marks.
「こんにちはロリタ。元気?」
Quotes within dialogue use 『』, the Japanese equivalent of single quotation marks.
「私はロリコンではありません。その無礼な言葉より、私を『紳士』または『ジェントルマン』を呼んでもらえませんか?」

If the text is voiced, but is not spoken, parentheses are used.
This would be a situation where a voice actor is reading a character's internal monologue, or the rare situation where a character has telepathy and is reading another character's mind.
I also see Japanese authors use parentheses to indicate whispering fairly often.

If you aren't sure about anything else, I'd recommend downloading a Japanese VN and looking for yourself.
Here's a free Japanese VN I personally love:
http://funamusea.com/story/wadanohara/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
sounds like made-up guru words
don't fall for their schemes and courses to get rich quick--they're the ones getting rich quick, not you

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Multichannel marketing refers to the practice of interacting with customers using a combination of indirect and direct communication channels – websites, retail stores, mail order catalogs, direct mail, email, mobile, etc. – and enabling customers to take action in response – preferably to buy your product or service – using the channel of their choice. In the most simplistic terms, multichannel marketing is all about choice.
the consumer picks one (1) outlet out of many in which they interact with the company, the important thing is that they *choose* which one

another site:
>Multichannel is much simpler in its intention, which is to distribute content and advertisements across various channels. A multichannel strategy makes an organization available to consumers online, in print, in-store, etc. The consumer can choose where they want to interact with the brand, however, content and engagements within these various channels are often very siloed.

>Omnichannel also makes brands accessible across online and offline channels, however, it goes a step further to ensure an integrated, seamless experience across each one. As consumers move across devices and online and offline platforms, transitions are seamless and messages are informed by prior encounters.

>An omnichannel strategy may give consumers the chance to find and purchase online, in-store, or a combination thereof - such as “buy online and pick up in-store”.
i think the big difference is that omni connects a brand's offline/online platforms together, emphasising "seemless transition" between everything. the multichannel approach is more disconnected, their platforms exist sort of separately

i hope i interpreted that correctly

>>1316747
Compassion meditation. The Center for Healthy Minds has a few free mp3s. The half hour one narrated by Helen Weng, who is a researcher but she could do voiceover work, is well researched and shows positive effects.

It's not "om" or watch your breath and certainly not "clear your mind". It's little bits of "may I be well and happy, may my loved one be well and happy, may this stranger be well and happy, may this person I find difficult be well and happy". There are others too like watching the breath or things like that, but this is my preferred one. It's really easy, the hardest part is sitting down to do it. I found it was positive, I heartily encourage you to look it up.

Just looked it up myself. Looks like they've gone app for Android and ios. You can sign up on the website to download the mp3s. https://centerhealthyminds.org/join-the-movement/compassion-training

Instead of posting on the internet, go out and volunteer somewhere. I'd say not just shovelling your neighbour's sidewalk which is a really nice thing to do, but something regular and routine every week away from your house. Since you're already wasting time you're not going to lose anything worth having except maybe a couple of bucks for transport. You might be around some like minded people who want to do good and do it well. You'll also be with real people and that's much better than the anonymising effect of Internet interaction. Instead of hiding behind your anonymity you'll have to deal with people more appropriately and there are people who will punch you in the face if you get too fresh with them which is good incentive, even if you do go to the gym. If you can find time for that, you can find time to refine your mind and attitude as well.

Just go out and help someone.

General interest link https://centerhealthyminds.org/join-the-movement/9-ways-to-stop-being-negative which might help.

App links at bottom https://hminnovations.org/well-being-tools

May you be well and happy.

>>1316503
Tolkien on Hompen

Concerning the translation work of The Hobbit to Swedish, Tolkien himself was not involved. Writing to Allen & Unwin in 1956 on the Dutch translation of The Lord of the Rings, Tolkien says:

"I wish to avoid a repetition of my experience with the Swedish translation of The Hobbit. I discovered that this had taken unwarranted liberties with the text and other details, without consultation or approval; it was also unfavourably criticized in general by a Swedish expert, familiar with the original, to whom I submitted it."
― J.R.R. Tolkien[3]

Later in the same year and writing on the same subject, Tolkien more specifically points out a source of dislike with Hompen to Rayner Unwin:

"May I say now at once that I will not tolerate any similar tinkering with the personal nomenclature. Nor with the name/word Hobbit. I will not have any more Hompen (in which I was not consulted), nor any Hobbel or what not."
― J.R.R. Tolkien[4]

The translation of the name 'Hobbit' to 'Hompe'[note 1] was not the only thing that annoyed Tolkien about this edition. Already in 1948, he wrote to Rosemary, a young fan, that "the picture of Gollum in the Swedish edition of The Hobbit makes him look huge."[5]

Some other curiosities about Zetterholm's translation are his renderings of 'Bilbo' to 'Bimbo' (!), 'elf' to 'alva' (disregarding the etymological connection, 'alva' carries connotations in Swedish which would rather translate it to 'fairy'), and 'goblin' to 'svartalf' ("darkelf").[2]

>>1316506
[...] Tolkien was also a pretty-legit illustrator... So, if anyone gets the okay to gripe about cover illustrations, and walk around in a tattered robe cursing in Elfish, it's him.

Here's a quote from a letter he wrote to Raynor Unwin (from The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien) after Ballantine's American paperback of The Hobbit was released in '65 with Barbara Remington's dubious illustrations of lions and 'pumpkins'

"I wrote to [Ballantine] expressing (with moderation) my dislike of the cover for The Hobbit. It was a short hasty note by hand, without a copy, but it was to this effect: I think the cover ugly; but I recognize that a main object of a paperback cover is to attract purchasers, and I suppose that you are better judges of what is attractive in USA than I am. I therefore will not enter into a debate about taste - (meaning though I did not say so: horrible colours and foul lettering) - but I must ask this about the vignette: what has it got to do with the story? Where is this place? Why a lion and emus? And what is the thing in the foreground with pink bulbs? [ed. - he would later call them "pumpkins"] I do not understand how anybody who had read the tale (I hope you are one) could think such a picture would please the author. ..."

It's a good question ? and he was right to ask it. Remington never got a chance to read the books and "didn't know what they were about" when she designed the Hobbit cover, as she said in an interview with Andwerve.

After the first five editions of the paperback, as noted by the Tolkein Library, Ballantine finally removed the lion. The pumpkins and emus, however, stayed.

>>1316671
>A lot of its syntax is overly concise, unintuitive, and overloaded

foo = 3
bar = 1
print (("foo","bar")[(foo<bar)])

What can we notice about this?
- it appears to be a ternary, but Python doesn't have ternaries
- it works by accident because of tuples and the intiness of truthy values: (foo<bar) is silently coerced from a conditional statement, into a boolean, then into an int
- the "parameters" are backwards compared to a C (and every other language) ternary, so if you're not paying attention your condition will be reversed
This is all kinda representative of what Python has become: it started off as a clean simple language more legible than bash but less verbose than c and java, but then feature after feature after feature was added to it, and now your average bit of "clever python" is a mess of brackets and colons and percents that all have special different meanings in this specific construct.

I can't really solve this problem.

lim x-> 4
(3 - sqrt(5+x)) / (2-sqrt(8-x)) =

I'm multiplying by the conjugate of the numerator,
Then the conjugate of the denominator, but I can't factor it from there.

[4x * (2+sqrt(8-x))] /
[(12+x) * (3*sqrt(5-x)) ]


If I try to insert the value for the point there, it gives infinity ( 64/(0*3) ), but the textbook says -2/3.

Any help would be appreciated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
plugging x=4 into the original, you get the indeterminate form 0/0
you can resolve it by applying l'hopital's rule, taking the derivative of the top and bottom separately then dividing again

d/dx [3-sqrt(5+x)] = -(1/2)(5+x)^(-1/2)

d/dx [2-sqrt(8-x)] = (1/2)(8-x)^(-1/2)

put it back together
[-(1/2)(5+x)^(-1/2)]/[(1/2)(8-x)^(-1/2)]

flip x factors to get rid of negative powers
-(1/2)sqrt(8-x)/(1/2)sqrt(5+x)

simplify

>>1316654
>Thanks. I guess I could try to figure that out. But we have yet to study derivatives.
>But is there no way to solve it without doing that?

What is the definition of a limit?

Surely you have seen something about the limit of the function y = f(x) at a is the value f(x) approaches for f(a+h) and f(a-h) as h --> 0 if and only if both of those values exist and approach the same value.

I.e. you look at the partial limits. As h is assumed to be positive there may exist a partial limit from below as a - h --> a and there may exist a partial limit from above as a + h --> a

If both partial limits exist, it is possible that only one or neither exists, and approach the same then we say the limit exist and is equal to those partial limits.

As an example of where the partial limits exist but are differently valued consider f(x) = 1/x and evaluate its partial limits at 0. They both exist but no limit exists at 0 for f(x).

Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.sub: How bad idea it is to disable secure boot on machine at work and boot of a flash drive?
posts.com:
Recently I discovered that computer's bios at work does not have password protection set up. I'm thinking that I'll disable secure boot and bring a flash drive with linux installed on it, boot from it and do my own thing whenever i get free time.

The only concern I have is that I don't know how exactly the secure boot works and how it may or may not behave or effect the windows installed on the machine if booted without it.
>May the windows send some kind of message to the admin that it has been booted without it?
>May the bitlocker somehow get fucked up by this and require recovery key which I don't know?
>May disabling it make it to forget the signatures thus making reenabling afterwards useless?

Maybe I'm overthinking it and it is much simpler. What do you think? Should I disable the secure boot just for the USB and reenable it for the windows? Or is it safe to boot into the windows with it being disabled? Should I worry about something else? Or should I completely let this thought go?

Some more info:
>The computer is meant for reading and writing work emails with really limited user privileges.
>As of now I'm the only person that is supposed to use this PC.
>Bitlocker requires pin on each boot which I know.
>The bios options seem to not be touched by anybody from the company.
>ThinkCenter M70q
>Picture is related.
>The machine is connected wirelessly to the company's network and can be disabled in the bios.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316468
>Bitlocker requires pin on each boot which I know.
Turning off Secure Boot will change the TPM's boot measurement and make Bitlocker require the recovery key.

This should be kinda obvious, because if it didn't you could just replace winload with your own executable that monkey-patched the kernel before running it and sent the bitlocker keys to Estonia.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316484
I see. What if I enable it afterwards? Will it change back or is changed permanently?

Thank you for your reply and for confirmation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316576
>Will it change back or is changed permanently?
It's not a case of "changing back", the TPM stores a list of keys* and unlock conditions for each key, and if the conditions aren't met the TPM won't unlock the key. One set of conditions is "boot measurements", so the TPM will unlock the bitlocker key depending if you secure-booted a microsoft-signed winload.efi that loaded the BCD entry that bitlocker expected, and won't if you didn't. Each boot is separate, it doesn't erase the keys in response to a failed boot. The intent of this is you could have two separate windows installs** (and also other OSes such as Linux) that all use the same TPM but don't have access to each other's bitlocker keys.

That said, there's nothing stopping the OS from clearing the TPM if it detects that Secure Boot is off, and the BIOS would be able to clear the TPM when you turn off Secure Boot, but I don't think either of them are supposed to do that. Microsoft is quite vague on this issue, saying that
>If the TPM is missing or changed or if BitLocker detects changes to the BIOS or UEFI code or configuration, critical operating system startup files, or the boot configuration, BitLocker enters recovery mode, and the user must enter a recovery password to regain access to the data.
It's not clear from reading this if recovery mode is a state that bitlocker changes to, or just what it does when the TPM won't give it the key it wants. Obviously if you actually perform a recovery, it will lock the key to this new TPM state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
* technically on TPM 2.0 the OS stores the keys, but the TPM encrypts them with its secret key and the OS can't decrypt them, so all the OS is really doing is providing blob storage
** dual-booting the same windows isn't a supported configuration, but I see no reason why it wouldn't work. If I'm reading it right, "path" is included in the default BCD validation profile, so each entry would lock the other out its keys https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/information-protection/bitlocker/bcd-settings-and-bitlocker

So in lame terms it should be working after enabling it again but it is unclear if the bitlocker lock itself in recovery key requirement once it enter this state, right?

Once again thank you for making things clearer for me.

I'll ask my familiar if he by any chance posses any computer with those features and I'll do a bit of experimenting on it beforehand.

I also read somewhere that it should be possible to sign the bootloader of your OS by yourself. Can the computer have it's own specific signature checks or are there only universal one? If I should be able to successfully boot my OS under secure boot on one machine then I should be able to boot it on any machine, right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316612
>I also read somewhere that it should be possible to sign the bootloader of your OS by yourself. Can the computer have it's own specific signature checks or are there only universal one? If I should be able to successfully boot my OS under secure boot on one machine then I should be able to boot it on any machine, right?
I would strongly recommend against doing that.
TPM measurement register PCR1 is the BIOS settings, at least the BIOS settings pertaining to booting the PC. I would be flabbergasted if the secure boot settings weren't measured by PCR1, and I would expect enrolling your own secure boot key to immediately lock you out of the keys stored in the TPM, possibly forever if you can't restore secure boot to the settings it was on.

However, this would realistically only happen if you contracted one in a third world country and ignored symptoms for multiple weeks. If you have lingering symptoms that loosely conform to those of a parasite infection, you're almost definitely overthinking it and the problem lies elsewhere. Antiparasitics can also be very tough on the body, so they're not something to use on a whim.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316350
/AAA/i

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316351
is that the same for all other fields?
>comment
>name
>trip

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316355
Yes. Filters are regular expression rules.
In '/AAA/i' the two '/' enclose the expression and the 'i' after is a flag to make the filter case insensitive.
If you want to filter a field that starts with 'AAA' you can do '/^AAA/i', for a field that ends in 'AAA' do '/AAA$/i', for a field that's exactly AAA combine both ^ and $ into '/^AAA$/i' . ^ and $ mean "begin with" and "end with" and have to be at the beginning and end of the string you want to search respectively.
Literal slashes are special characters so they need to be escaped.
If you want to filter '/WWG/' with the slashes you need to precede each / with a \ so your filter will look like this: '/\/AAA\//i'. Again, if you want to filter a field that starts with /WWG/, do '/^\/\/AAA\//i'.

Learn regex here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Regular_Expressions
Test your rules here: https://regex101.com/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1315880
get a piano with weighted keys. go to udemy and take the read music fast course and the beginner piano course by the same guy, you should be able to get through both quickly. now get in person lessons with a teacher and use whatever materials they suggest.

if for whatever reason you can't get in person lessons a hungarian musician named bela bartok taught his son how to play piano by writing notes on a napkin and telling him to play it. those napkins were archived and compiled into mikrokosmos which you can find online for free like here

https://archive.org/details/BartokMikrokosmonVolI/page/n1/mode/2up

There's people on youtube that play through the napkin compilation like this person here so take a look at how other people play it if you're not sure you're doing it right

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WJ7vVQMdxoI

your goal is to play everything exactly as written, eventually getting up to the tempo required with no mistakes. once you get through the first two volumes you will be considered a beginner pianist instead of useless pianist. however since all you played to learn was hungarian folk music you're going to play like dracula. far more based than someone that used alfred's beginner piano and can play every boomer chrismas song

posts.com:
WebM for Lazys v3.22.0, Mode Variable, Enable Audio, adjust Video CRF from experience derived from duration and dimensions and how busy the source is.
It's depends a lot on the source: fast dits, zooms, pans and rotates are bitrate hogs; nice calm oldschool animations are best. My examples: >>>/wsg/4925354 is 90 seconds at 464p; >>>/aco/6998967 very busy, very NSFW with 14 seconds at 720p; the "scratchy" Josephine Baker one took 3 MB to do just 20 seconds at 400p; >>>/wsg/4929484 is 60+ seconds at 1080p but I had to force quality down to fit (artefacts visible). I sometimes leave my CRF settings in the filename. Also, avoid resizing as it degrades quality, better is shorter durations.
Last, I rarely use ffmpeg command line for difficult cases.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316202
If you're expecting the "++i" to do the trick, it won't.
The sequence in which the for loop is evaluated is irrelevant to what you have written there, but while in other contexts the i is incremented as soon as the line is reached, in here it is not.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1316275
>while in other contexts the i is incremented as soon as the line is reached, in here it is not.
It kinda is, if you had
for (i=0; i<3; printf("%d", ++i)) { ... }
the ++i would behave as expected.

The important thing is that c for loops consist of
for (<declaration>; <condition>; <iteration>) <body>
and they expand to
{
<declaration>
start-of-loop:
if (<condition>) break;
<body>
<iteration>
goto start-of-loop;
}

As we can see, the entire iteration block finishes executing before the condition block starts, so differences between ++i and i++ matter within the iteration block, but don't matter if the increment is in the iteration block and the test is in the condition block.

posts.com:
>>1316256
More robust method than layering and correcting:

1- Layer / Raster Mask / From Transparency
This will split the RGBA into RGB and alpha (second and third image).
The alpha becomes a layer mask to the layer.

2- Select the layer mask and copy it into a layer.
This is to be able to work on it.

3- Make a rectangular selection of the gradient at the bottom,
copy it into a new layer and stretch it horizontally to cover the whole width.

4-Set the blending mode to divide and merge the layer.
This gives you the fourth image.

4-Finally, copy the adjusted alpha into the layer mask and export to PNG.
This gives a pixel perfect result, with no fuzziness or darkness in sharp corners.
